page.title: International reactions to the 2011 Egyptian revolution

rev.diff:
Line 1: Line 1:
{{current|date=January 2011}}
{{current|date=January 2011}}
  +
{{About|International reactions to the 2011 Egyptian protests|International reactions|Domestic responses|Domestic responses to the 2011 Egyptian protests|the main article|2011 Egyptian protests}}
'''International reactions to the [[2011 Egyptian protests]]''' have generally been either measured or supportive of the [[Egyptian people]], with most governments and organisations calling for non-violent responses on both sides and peaceful moves towards reform. Whilst the protesters have been calling for [[President of Egypt|Egyptian President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]] to step down immediately,<ref>{{cite news|author=Al-Shalchi, Hadeel; El Deeb, Sarah|title=Mubarak Says He Will Not Seek Re-Election|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/feb/1/massive-crowds-across-egypt-demand-mubaraks-ouster/?page=|accessdate=2 February 2011|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[The Washington Times]]'')|date=1 February 2011}}</ref> most foreign governments have stopped short of this demand, due to concerns about the consequences of a power vacuum on the stability of [[Egypt]] and the [[Middle East]]. Some Middle Eastern leaders have expressed support for Mubarak. Meanwhile many governments have issued [[travel advisory|travel advisories]] and begun making attempts at evacuating their citizens from the country.
'''International reactions to the [[2011 Egyptian protests]]''' have generally been either measured or supportive of the [[Egyptian people]], with most governments and organisations calling for non-violent responses on both sides and peaceful moves towards reform. Whilst the protesters have been calling for [[President of Egypt|Egyptian President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]] to step down immediately,<ref>{{cite news|author=Al-Shalchi, Hadeel; El Deeb, Sarah|title=Mubarak Says He Will Not Seek Re-Election|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/feb/1/massive-crowds-across-egypt-demand-mubaraks-ouster/?page=|accessdate=2 February 2011|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[The Washington Times]]'')|date=1 February 2011}}</ref> most foreign governments have stopped short of this demand, due to concerns about the consequences of a power vacuum on the stability of [[Egypt]] and the [[Middle East]]. Some Middle Eastern leaders have expressed support for Mubarak. Meanwhile many governments have issued [[travel advisory|travel advisories]] and begun making attempts at evacuating their citizens from the country.
